task.summary: Default task

Solve medium design a leaderboard which supports updating scores of a player as well as finding the top k scores using hashmap + treemap (priority queue)
Leveraged prior learning of using treemap instead of priority queue when deletion is required.

Solve medium and a bit tricky to implement, find the longest length of consecutive 1's in a matrix in horizontal, vertical, diagonal and anti diagonal directions using 4D DP and leveraging the fact that row-col and row+col for elements in same diagonal are same
Learnings -- row-col can be negative, so if we want to use array for storing current length of consecutive 1's seen in the diagonal, we need to make it positive by adding +n (column length)

Solve easy find whether it's possible to transform the given pieces of array into target array by trying to concatenate them in any way possible, by tracking the leader of each piece and the entire piece.
It was a bit tricky to implement though, not an easy question! Need to make sure the entire piece is fulfilled as partial pieces are not allowed.

Solve medium and extremely tricky to optimize given a list of words, find which words are a subsequence of the provided string. I got AC by keeping track of occurrence of each character in the target string and see if you can find an index > previous index.
An optimized approach would be to maintain a mapping of character to the list of words that require that character. As we traverse the string, update the mappings.

Solve medium and extremely tricky find no of fleets that will be formed by cars starting at different positions and travelling at different speed towards target using greedy. Tricky thing to note was that a car starting earlier and reaching in t time will block cars starting later and reaching in x < t time. So they will become part of an existing fleet.

Solve hard and extremely tricky count no of distinct subsequences in a string, that can contain duplicate characters using o(n^2) and o(n) DP. Please read the comments inside the source for better understanding.

Solve medium and tricky remove comments from a source code using string parsing by visualizing it as a state machine. Although I knew how to write the code, still I figured to see the solution in order to "save me from humiliation".
Learnings -- Trick to solving string parsing question is to visualize it as a state machine i.e if /* is encountered switch to a different mode and carefully decide each mode's priority. It will make code very easier.
Solve medium find the corresponding node of a target node in the cloned tree by walking both the tress simultaneously.
Solve medium sort a matrix diagonally such that each diagonal is sorted separately by maintaining a map of diagonalId to priority queue of elements present in that diagonal

Solve medium and extremely tricky find the largest sum possible that is divisible by 3 using DP.
Leveraged prior learnings of using mod whenever divisibility is involved. Here we need to do the same by using current mod and greatest sum possible at previous element. State transitions are similar to previously solved house robber.

Solve medium design a time based key value data structure that provides the value of a key at a timestamp <= provided timestamp using map + treemap combination.
Leveraged prior learnings of solving SnapshotArray

Solve medium count all beautiful numbers of n digits, where we can place a digit on the ith index only if either the digit divides the index or the index divides the digit using backtracking or bitmasking
Leveraged prior learnings of using (bitmask, current node/index) as an identifier for memoization during bitmasking.

Solve medium and extremely tricky find the lexicographically smallest permutation of 1,2,3..n that satisfies pattern like I and D by greedy. Consider the base case of all I's, it would be 1,2,3...n. Whenever D is found, need to reverse the portion to find the smallest valid permutation.
Got lost while trying to incrementally build the solution by tracking length of I's and D's and placing numbers accordingly.

Solve medium find all increasing subsequences using bottom up DP. Care must be taken to handle duplicates. Got a couple of WA's due to missing edge cases like handling cases where duplicates occur > 2 times [1,3,3,3] and duplicates are not contiguous [10,9,10]
Rename variable to make it more similar to it's usage
Fix incorrect distance check when some node is unreachable
Simplify code by using Math.min() instead
Add gotchas in count distinct subsequences
Simplify topological sort by using enums as states instead of maintaining two different arrays
Solve medium remove all adjacent duplicate characters in string which are of k length using stack.
Simplify code by just considering whether we can find a subset with targetSum = totalSum/2. Each element has two options, either be part of the subset or be excluded from it. Try both the options.
Solve medium remove duplicates from a sorted linked list using dummy node

Solve medium design data structure to represent browser history that supports going back and forward k steps in history using arraylist and ensuring that we overwrite the index, if we are at inner indices instead of creating a new list and appending to the end of it. This smart overwrite logic ensures we work in O(1) time for all operations

Solve easy find out how many person's can be satisfied from given set of cookies if a person needs atleast a cookie of specific size to get satisfied using greedy by sorting the size of cookies and greed of each persons.

Solve hard and extremely tricky rearrange a string such that same characters are placed at k distance apart using greedy approach. Couple of tricks were used 1. Use PQ based on decreasing frequency as the characters that occurs the most should be placed first 2. To ensure that we don't place characters early (<k distance), use a queue for simulating characters that are waiting. Add the head of the queue back to PQ only if queue.size()==k

Solve hard and extremely tricky design a data structure that supports adding ranges and removing ranges using ordered map. Each portion itself is a medium problem of its own ! To support addRange() we need to merge overlapping intervals by removing all overlapping intervals and at the end introducing the final merged range. To support removeRange() we can add the range to insert a merged interval and then remove the entire interval only to introduce the slices that needs not to removed ie. the portion on the left and right of target range. Very tricky operation but it simplifies the code a lot

Solve hard and extremely tricky find critical connections in a network using tarzan's algorithm for detecting back edges.
Keep track of the time a node was first visited, if it's neighbourTime > firstVisitedTime, we have a critical connection. Meanwhile if a node is connected to a node with smaller time, this means there is another path to this node hence current path isn't critical. Keep updating the time of an index by taking the min of neighbourTime and curNodeTime

Solve medium given a set of rooms where each room has a set of keys, find whether it's possible to visit all rooms using UnionFind. A bit optimization trick to avoid visited array was to use a dummy room to perform union with.
Reminder to self, union find can be applied only on undirected graphs and this problem isn't exactly an undirected graph.

Solve medium and a bit tricky find the number of closed islands i.e find the 0's that are completely surrounded by 1's by inverting the lookup criteria. We know the cells at the border are definitely not surrounded, so we mark all the cells connected to the border water cells. The water cells left are closed.

Solve medium and extremely tricky coloring game where first player has chosen a node and we have to choose a marker node. Now after this each player can only choose nodes that are directly connected to the nodes of same color.
Trick was to realize that best option for player2 would be to choose any of the 3 connected nodes to first players chosen node i.e left child, right child or it's parent. Doing so will block first player to choose any of it's subtree.

Solve medium and extremely tricky to do it in O(1) space complexity, given nodes of a n-ary tree, find the root node. Simple solution is to use a visited set to keep track of nodes that were visited because they are a children of some other node. Root node will never be visited because it's not a children of any node. But this approach requires additional space.
In order to reduce space complexity we have to leverage the insight that all other nodes except root node are visited twice. So if we perform xor on the values, only root node will remain.

Solve easy find whether two string arrays result in same string upon concatenation or not using O(1) space via two pointers approach. Keep four pointers, 2 for word index and 2 for char index inside word. Increment the word index pointer if char index has reached the end of the current word. At the end check if all the words have been verified in both the arrays.

Add constraints in the problem statement along with explanation of not using the curSum as a key in memoization because the numbers chosen so far can uniquely represent the dp state. We are not restricting ourselves to an index
Add approach and related line sweep problems
Add clarification on why DP doesn't work for this problem because this problem has cycles in recurrence relation
Update comment
Add comment for evaluation future nested string expressions
Add approach and simplify code by removing visited arrays because the given graph is a DAG
Simplify code by introducing enum states instead of two boolean[] array; visited and toDo
Simplify code by removing redundant null checks

Solve medium and a bit tricky, merge all emails associated with the same person by performing union find on strings.
Union find on strings is a bit tricky as we need to either have a unique identifier associated with each string, here we can use the index as an id, if we see an email is already associated with another index, we perform union on those two indices.
Add comment to explain the additional code in union() operation on strings
Add clarifications on handling duplicate elements
Add comments and time complexity in MostStonesRemovedWithSameRowOrSameColumn
Update comment regarding handling of parallel edges
Add comment to solve the problem in another way

Solve hard and extremely tricky represent data stream as disjoint intervals by merging consecutive integers ie. 1,2,3,4 are merged to form [1,4] using treeMap
Learnings -- To handle interval related problem, always ensure that there is no overlapping interval before or after an operation, so whenever do something, remove overlapped intervals and introduce a merged interval

Solve hard and extremely tricky find the min no of flips required so that array does not have any 0. Whenever flip is performed, we have to flip k consecutive bits. Need to use greedy ie. whenever we see a 0, flip k consecutive bits. If we actually flip it, time complexity would be o(nk), instead we perform virtual flips i.e we keep track of indices till which we have to perform flips and size of queue would indicate the no of flips performed. If A[i] == 1 and we have performed even bits, A[i] is still 1, so skip it.
Add problem statement and approach for counting prime numbers < n using sieve of eratosthenes

MESSAGE.value: Solve hard and extremely tricky rearrange a string such that same characters are placed at k distance apart using greedy approach. Couple of tricks were used 1. Use PQ based on decreasing frequency as the characters that occurs the most should be placed first 2. To ensure that we don't place characters early (<k distance), use a queue for simulating characters that are waiting. Add the head of the queue back to PQ only if queue.size()==k
